scenarios.description: No safety car or VSC throughout the race. Pure pace strategy. Historically happens 22% at this circuit.
SC deployed in the opening phase. Common from lap 1 incidents. Creates an early free pit stop window — changes the entire race.
SC during the primary pit window. Splits the field between those who have pitted and those who haven't.
SC in the final phase. Can force an unplanned extra stop or give leaders a free pit. Dramatic strategy implications.
VSC deployed but no full SC. Smaller time gain from pitting under VSC (~40% of SC saving). Rewards opportunistic stops.
Two separate SC events. Chaos scenario — 2-stop strategies get two free pit windows. Highly favourable for aggressive approaches.
Tyre deg is 30% worse than the model predicts. Track temp higher, graining, or unexpected abrasion. Favours multi-stop strategies.
Tyre deg is 25% better than predicted. Track evolution, cooler conditions, or rubber build-up. Favours extending stints.
Worst-case combo: incident in opening laps AND tyres wearing faster than expected. Strongly favours 2-stop strategies.
Best-case for conservative strategies: no interruptions and tyres lasting longer than expected. 1-stop heaven.

decision_triggers.trigger: If late safety car (lap 43–67): switch to 1-stop M→S
If early sc + high degradation: switch to 2-stop H→M→S
If higher than expected degradation: switch to 2-stop M→H→S
If early safety car (lap 1–17): switch to 2-stop H→M→S
If lower than expected degradation: switch to 1-stop S→H
If mid-race safety car (lap 18–42): switch to 1-stop H→S
If clean race — no safety car: switch to 2-stop M→S→H
If double safety car: switch to 1-stop M→H
If clean race + low degradation: switch to 1-stop H→S
